intro: Horkelia fusca var. capitata, commonly known as the Sierra foothill bluecup, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its compact growth habit and showy blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid conditions. It has small, narrow leaves and produces clusters of bell-shaped flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. This species is often found in meadows and open woodlands at elevations ranging from 1,500 to 6,000 feet.
